review.title: P-trac Procedure: The Dispersion and Neutralization of Contrasts in Lexicon
review.abstract: Cognitive acoustic cues have an important role in shaping the phonological structure of language as a means to optimal communication. In this paper we introduced P-trac procedure in order to track dispersion of contrasts in different contexts in lexicon. The results of applying P-trac procedure to the case of dispersion of contrasts in pre- consonantal contexts and in consonantal positions of CVCC sequences in Persian provide Evidence in favor of phonetic basis of dispersion argued by Licensing by Cue hypothesis and the Dispersion Theory of Contrast. The P- trac procedure is proved to be very effective in revealing the dispersion of contrasts in lexicon especially when comparing the dispersion of contrasts in different contexts.

sections.text: The results of applying the P-Trac method to the case of dispersion of opposites in preconsonant contexts and in consonant positions of CVCC sequences in Persian provide evidence for the phonetic basis of dispersion argued by Licensing. It has been proven that the Ptrac method is very effective in dividing contrasts in lexicon, especially when it comes to comparing the dispersion of contrasts in different contexts. It has been argued that phonological constraints are used for phonological patterns. Recent studies on the role of articulation / perception of phonological factors in phonological phenomena have provided consistent explanations (e.g. Flemming, 1995, 1995, 1997, 1997, 1997, 1997, 1997, 1997).

sections.heading: 3.1. Data
sections.text: Just like the lexicon CELEX (Baayen et al., 1995) for some Western languages, FLexicon is a database containing information about the lexicon of the Persian language. This database contains 54409 words and their phonemic transcription. Syllable structure in Persian is very simple because it does not allow complex breaks. CV, CVC and CVCC are the only three possible syllable structures. Therefore, the formation of lexemes can be deterministic.

sections.heading: 4. Using P-trac procedure to compare the dispersion of contrasting features in consonantal positions
sections.text: CVCC syllables in Persian. In this experiment, the P-trac method was used to find the dispersion of type, place and expressive characteristics in and positions of syllables in FLexicon. The aim of this experiment is to find out how the distribution of high-contrast characteristics is related to the amount of perceptibility of the clues argued by the Licensing Cue hypothesis (Steriade, 1997) and the dispersion theory of contrast (Flemming 1995, 2004, 2006). Phonemic transcriptions of lexemes were again used as input into the P-trac method.

sections.heading: 4.1. Applying P-trac procedure
sections.text: All the different CVCC syllables with their type frequency, the frequency of the syllable in the lexicon, were extracted and, using the P-trac method, all the minimum sequence pairs were found and for each context (consonants in and position of) the contrasting characteristics were counted. As in the previous experiment for each minimum sequence pair, the frequencies [context, feature] were added by the minimum type frequency of the members of the minimum sequence pair. Thus, for example, for / band / and / pand / minimum sequence pairs, if the type frequency is of / band / 200 and that of / pand / 300, the frequencies [_ and voice] were added by 200.

sections.heading: 4.2. Results
sections.text: Diagram-3: Frequency distribution of contrasting characteristics in C1, C2 and C3 positions in C1VC2C3 syllables of the Persian lexicon. As can be seen, the frequency of contrasts is highest in the prevocal context (3404 contrasts), in the medial context (1015 contrasts) and minimally in the preconsonant context (791 contrasts), whatever the contrasting characteristic is. Gradually, the frequency of contrasting characteristics decreases from characteristic to characteristic and from characteristic to characteristic.

sections.heading: 5. Discussion
sections.text: The results of the P-trac method, applied to the case of contrasting characteristics in preconsonant contexts of clusters in CVCC syllables, show that the dispersion of contrasting characteristics is exactly in line with the predictions made by the cue hypothesis and the dispersion theory of contrast. According to Wright, 2004, the frequency of contrasting characteristics in preconsonant contexts is gradually decreasing from the manner in which contrasts and from place to place of contrasting contexts. According to Wright, the extent of the perceptibility of acoustic characteristics is in precontrasting contexts, places and intonations of characteristics that exhibit exactly the same pattern. The more clearly the perception of a characteristic in a precontrasting characteristic in a precontrasting context, the more frequently it was used as a contrasting characteristic.

sections.heading: 6. Conclusion
sections.text: The results of applying the P-trac method to the case of contrast scattering in preconsonant contexts and in consonant positions of CVCC sequences in Persian provide evidence for a phonetic basis for contrast scattering, which is argued by the Licensing by Cue hypothesis and the dispersion theory of contrast. P-trac has proven to be very effective in detecting contrast scattering in the lexicon, especially when it provides a means of comparing contrast scattering in different contexts.

referenceMentions.context: Functional goals accounted for phonological constraints have been reported in several works (Zipf, 1949; Martinet, 1952; Martinet, 1955; Lindblom, 1986; Lindblom, 1990), but there are arguments against functional basis of phonology (Ohala, 1993; Labov, 1994; Trask, 1996).

Phonetically-based phonology, on the other hand, argues to provide such consistent predictions based on the assumption that phonotactics should ensure the perceptibility of cues to segmental contrasts (Kawasaki, 1982; Ohala, 1992; Flemming, 1995; Krichner, 1997; Steriade, 1999; Wright, 2004; Flemming, 2007).

Phonetically-based phonology, on the other hand, argues to provide such consistent predictions based on the assumption that phonotactics should ensure the perceptibility of cues to segmental contrasts (Kawasaki, 1982; Ohala, 1992; Flemming, 1995; Krichner, 1997; Steriade, 1999; Wright, 2004; Flemming, 2007).

Phonetically-based phonology, on the other hand, argues to provide such consistent predictions based on the assumption that phonotactics should ensure the perceptibility of cues to segmental contrasts (Kawasaki, 1982; Ohala, 1992; Flemming, 1995; Krichner, 1997; Steriade, 1999; Wright, 2004; Flemming, 2007).

Phonetically-based phonology, on the other hand, argues to provide such consistent predictions based on the assumption that phonotactics should ensure the perceptibility of cues to segmental contrasts (Kawasaki, 1982; Ohala, 1992; Flemming, 1995; Krichner, 1997; Steriade, 1999; Wright, 2004; Flemming, 2007).

Phonetically-based phonology, on the other hand, argues to provide such consistent predictions based on the assumption that phonotactics should ensure the perceptibility of cues to segmental contrasts (Kawasaki, 1982; Ohala, 1992; Flemming, 1995; Krichner, 1997; Steriade, 1999; Wright, 2004; Flemming, 2007).

Phonetically-based phonology, on the other hand, argues to provide such consistent predictions based on the assumption that phonotactics should ensure the perceptibility of cues to segmental contrasts (Kawasaki, 1982; Ohala, 1992; Flemming, 1995; Krichner, 1997; Steriade, 1999; Wright, 2004; Flemming, 2007).
Some laterals have cues spreading over an entire syllable (Wright, 2004).
Based largely on Wright (2004), a number of cues to place, manner and voicing are introduced here.
Manner cues are more resistant to noise masking and are more perceptually salient compared to voice and place cues (Wright, 2004).

Cues to voicing are periodicity, VOT, the presence and the amplitude of aspiration noise, and duration cues which can be irrecoverable for stops in syllable final and preconsonantal contexts (Wright, 2004).

The study of perceptual cues has revealed that cues to voicing contrasts are weaker than cues to place contrasts and cues to place contrasts are weaker than cues to manner contrasts especially in preconsonantal contexts (Wright, 2004).
According to Wright (2004), the perceptibility of cues decreases from cues to manner contrasts to that of place contrasts and from cues to place contrasts to that of voicing contrasts.
Just like CELEX lexicon (Baayen et al., 1995) for some western languages, FLexicon is a database which contains information about the lexicon of Persian language.
According to (Wright, 2004) the amount of perceptibility of acoustic cues of manner, place and voicing features has exactly the same pattern.

The perceptibility of cues is maximal in onset position, medial in last coda position and minimal in preconsonantal position (Wright, 2004) and has the exact pattern of the dispersion of contrasts in those contexts.
